document.docAuthor: Breitkreuz, Laura C. V., Ohl, Michael & Engel, Michael S.
document.docTitle: Arpactophilus merle Breitkreuz, Ohl & Engel, 2016, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A review of the New Caledonian Arpactophilus (Hymenoptera: Crabronidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the New Caledonian Arpactophilus (Hymenoptera: Crabronidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Arpactophilus merle
is the only New Caledonian species in the genus with multiple teeth on the inner side of the pretarsal claws. Additionally of that the species can be distinguished by the combination of a yellow mesoscutellum (
Fig. 19
), a black mesoscutum, and a laterally yellow, medially brown clypeus that has a medially projecting apical margin with a broad V-shaped incision (
Fig. 71
).
Description. FEMALE: Total length 3.8–4.8 mm , mean = 4.6 mm ; forewing length 2.5 –3.0 mm, mean = 2.8 mm .
MALE: Difference from female aside from genitalic structures: clypeus more blunt; generally lighter brown; mesoscutellum light brown. Metasomal sternum VIII neither broadened nor narrowed.

Remarks.
Arpactophilus merle
is easily identifiable by its unique pattern of coloration. As in
A. nere
,
A. paici
, and
A. scutellaris
the mesoscutellum is mostly yellow, but
A. merle
differs from these species in the coloration of head and body. The species has dorsally truncate yellow markings on the frons and a laterally yellow and medially brown clypeus (
Fig. 71
). Similarly to
A. nere
the body is mostly dark brown, but the two species are most easily distinguishable by the form of the clypeus and labrum, which is both have pointed long teeth in
A. nere
(
Fig. 77
). Some specimens of
A. fwai
have a yellowish mesoscutellum, but they differ from
A. merle
and
A. nere
by having a completely yellow clypeus (
Fig. 55
) and from
A. scutellaris
and
A. paici
by their dark brown or black ventral meso- and metasoma (
Fig. 56
).

Etymology. The species is named after the first author’s sister Merle Breitkreuz. The name is treated as a noun in apposition.
